_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary    



In order to comply with the Risk Management Program regulations, 40 CFR Part 68, mandated under the accidental release provisions of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, the International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) is re-submitting this Risk Management Plan for the East Fishkill Facility.



Ammonia at greater than 20% is currently the only substance which is stored at a quantity greater than the respective reporting threshold and required to be included in this submission.  Ammonia at greater than 20% is stored at the Ammonia Treatment Plant and is covered by Prevention Program 2.  

 

Prevention Program Level 2:  Ammonia Treatment Plant



The Process Hazard Review (PHR) Team for Ammonia Treatment Plant is comprised of the following: Ammonia Treatment Plant Engineer (team leader), Treatment Plant operator, Site Risk Management Plan Preparer, Regulatory Engineer, and Site Fire Marshall.  The results of each PHR are recorded and maintained on file.



Operating procedures for the Ammonia Treatment Plant were originally written by the manufacturer and design firms, with input from Ammonia Treatment Plant Engineer and involved employees using technical process data and safety information.  Changes to the operating procedures are made by the Ammonia Treatment Plant Engineer and/or Lead Operator.  The operating procedures are reviewed annually by Ammonia Treatment Plant Engineer, all operators, and the department manager.  The Ammonia Treatment Plant operating and maintenance procedures are maintained on-line and are available to appropriate Ammonia Treatment Plant Personnel (i.e., engineer, operators, manager).



Training for the Ammonia Treatment Plant Operation is formulated and tracked by the  Ammonia Treatment Plant Engineer and training records are maintained by managers of D/9XMA and D92D.



Incident investigation program follows the IBM incident report procedure in the Safety & Health Manual for fact determination, root cause a

nalysis and recommendation implementation.



A maximum of 150,000 pounds of aqueous ammonia (25%) are inventoried as a result of reclaiming dilute aqueous ammonia to produce a  product. 



The toxic end point from a worse case release of aqueous ammonia has been calculated to be 3.4 miles using the RMP*Comp model.



The toxic end point from an alternative release case of aqueous ammonia has been calculated to be 0.6 miles  using the RMP*Comp model.



Release prevention of aqueous ammonia includes the use of vents, relief valves, check valves, scrubber, manual shutoffs, automatic shutoff, interlocks, alarms and procedures, backup pumps, and grounding equipment.,   Operator refresher training and system update training are conducted as prescribed in the operator training program.  All incidents are investigated to determine root cause and system deficiency correction.



No accidents/incidents have occurred involving the Ammonia Treatment Plant in the past 5 years.



The Facility emergency response plan defines response organizations, coordination with local emergency responders, equipment, response procedures, training, notifications procedures and drills.  The plan is updated according to the recommendations resulting from system deficiencies identified by periodic drills.
